title.narrative: Building Resilient Communities in Lebanon: An Integrated Approach to Livelihoods and Income Generation for Vulnerable Populations

description.narrative: Long Term Goal 1: Enhance resilience of local institutions through capacity building. The proposed intervention aims to revitalize existing institutions within target communities that can provide employment support, in addition to skills building support for vulnerable populations/ Long-Term Goal 2: Build the micro-economic resilience and social capital of vulnerable individuals, through access to employment services./ Long-Term Goal 3: Build market resilience through support for private sector.

Outcome Pathway A: Building the capacity of SDCs leads to an improved delivery of livelihood-related services/ Outcome Pathway B: Improving the technical and soft skills of vulnerable individuals to ensure increased participation in the private sector job market / Outcome Pathway C: Improving the capacity of the private sector leads to growth and job creation

Project activities: Activity 1.1. A market resource guide and new/improved training curriculum is developed for every supported SDC/ Activity 1.2. An action plan is developed for every supported SDC/ Activity 1.3. Relevant livelihood-related assets, training and renovations are provided to every supported SDC/ Activity 2.1. Vulnerable individuals are provided with relevant market-based TVET and soft skill trainings through SDCs and/or public/private service providers/ Activity 2.2. Trained vulnerable individuals are inserted into paid apprenticeship programs/ Activity 2.3. Vulnerable individuals are provided with labour market information, career guidance, counselling and job matching services/ Activity 3.1. MSMEs are provided with counselling and coaching, including the establishment of linkages to existing business development services.
Social Develpment Centers (SDCs), students, individuals, SMEs and Cooperatives

activity-date.narrative: The inception phase started on 2nd February 2017 and it is expected to last until August 2017. After that the project implementation will last until December 2019.

Communities play an active role in developing income generation and/or livelihood opportunities (including access to natural resources). Local institutions improve their delivery of livelihood-related trainings to vulnerable individuals.
Number and % of communities in programme areas that have adopted and are implementing livelihood protection strategies

description.narrative: 'Communities' is understood here as 'supported local institutions'. 'Livelihood’: A livelihood comprises the capabilities, assets (including both material and social resources) and activities required for a means of living - A way to support themselves financially. A livelihood is sustainable when it can cope with and recover from stress and shocks and maintain or enhance its capabilities and assets both now and in the future, while not undermining the natural resource base. Livelihood assets include: human capital (skills, knowledge, health and ability to work), social capital (informal networks, relationships of trust, etc.) natural capital (land, social, water forests and fisheries), physical capital (basic infrastructure) and financial capital (savings, credit and income). ‘Implementing livelihood protection strategies’ are communal strategies to assure livelihoods to secure one’s physical well-being and ultimately prevent the (re)occurrence of conflicts, instability or irregular migration, e.g. by jointly making better use of or improving access to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Communities, men and women increasingly benefit from employment. Vulnerable individuals increase their participation to the private sector job market.
Number of direct jobs supported by targeted companies

description.narrative: All ‘jobs supported’ in a company targeted by your intervention, regardless if the job existed before the intervention or after, or whether the job employs a programme beneficiary or not. This regards job creation by MSMEs through activity 2.4, but excludes self-employment. ‘Jobs’: A paid job, based on the local definition of a working week (e.g. 5 days per week/240 days per year), with or without a contract, paid roughly at the market wage rate. Thus, this indicator includes not just (the aggregated full-time equivalent of) jobs worked by seasonal, contractual and part time employees, but also informal employment.

title.narrative: Communities, men and women increasingly benefit from self-employment activities. MSMEs increase their financial viability, productivity and job creation.
Number and % of programme beneficiaries who started a business / self-employment activity and sustained it six months after they started

description.narrative: Business’ is understood here as an organization or economic system for exchanging products and/or services with costumers in order to make a profit in the formal or informal economy. A business may include the hiring of staff/personnel to work as contracted labourer. ‘Self-employment’ is understood as a situation in which an individual works for himself or herself (instead of working for an employer who pays him/her a salary or a wage), to earn her/his living; using knowledge, skills and taking minimum risk.

title.narrative: (Sustainable) Income-generating and livelihood opportunities (incl. for IDPs and refugees) have been created in a conflict sensitive manner, leading to jobs, income and more resilient communities
Number and % of programme beneficiaries who report ability to meet current and future (next 12 months) household needs

description.narrative: Programme beneficiaries' is defined here as beneficiaries completing at least one TVET/ soft skill course provided by supported by the programme, or beneficiaries benefiting from the MSME support (whether part of an already existing MSME or not), or beneficiaries benefiting from the job matching / career counselling support (activity 2.3), irrespective combinations of supports. Individuals working in SDCs are not considered as programme beneficiaries. ‘Household needs’: the minimum of resources necessary for the long-term physical well-being of one’s household, i.e. excluding psycho-social needs. Relate to more than financial needs; it normally includes access to food (e.g. through increased own agricultural and/or livestock production), shelter, water (e.g. wells), education (to secure a basic living, nothing more…), healthcare, etc. 'Ability’: is for this indicator defined as any of the following 4 levels (of having the minimum of resources necessary for the long-term physical well-being of one’s household) on a scale from 0 to 6 [note: one cannot answer by choosing a ‘sublevel’ in between these 4 distinct levels] 0: not at all able to meet household needs, 2: partially able to meet household needs, 4: almost able to meet household needs, 6: able to meet household needs ‘Future needs’ refers to the expected needs of a beneficiary in 12 months’ time (when, possibly, beneficiaries can reap more fruits of the support they have received, because for instance distributed seeds will have become harvested food). A beneficiary that is ‘able to meet current and future (in 12 months) household needs’ is for this indicator defined as a beneficiary whose average ‘score’ is either 5 or 6 points,

title.narrative: (Sustainable) Income-generating and livelihood opportunities (incl. for IDPs and refugees) have been created in a conflict sensitive manner, leading to jobs, income and more resilient communities
Number and % of programme beneficiaries who have reported a reduction of negative social/economic interaction across intra-societal divides over the last 6 months.

description.narrative: Programme beneficiaries' is defined here as beneficiaries completing at least one TVET/ soft skill course provided by supported by the programme, or beneficiaries benefiting from the MSME support (whether part of an already existing MSME or not), or beneficiaries benefiting from the job matching / career counselling support (activity 2.3), irrespective combinations of supports. Individuals working in SDCs are not considered as programme beneficiaries. ‘Negative social or economic interaction across intra-societal divides’: A supposed lack of interaction/exchanges of a social (e.g. exchanging views) or economic nature (e.g. an economic transaction), between a representative from a group or party within a society that does not easily exchange with a representative from another groups or parties, due to a variety of historical reasons, e.g. ethnic rivalry / existence of social or political conflicts / power or gender imbalances / political affiliation, etc. Said interactions or transactions would in itself make social or economic sense, but are lacking because of the described negative socio-economic interaction (rivalry, conflict, social tension, etc).

title.narrative: (Sustainable) Income-generating and livelihood opportunities (incl. for IDPs and refugees) have been created in a conflict sensitive manner, leading to jobs, income and more resilient communities
Number and % of programme beneficiaries who report reduced personal grievances [e.g. those related to conflict, instability or irregular migration] regarding income / livelihoods.

description.narrative: Programme beneficiaries' is defined here as beneficiaries completing at least one TVET/ soft skill course provided by supported by the programme, or beneficiaries benefiting from the MSME support (whether part of an already existing MSME or not), or beneficiaries benefiting from the job matching / career counselling support (activity 2.3), irrespective combinations of supports. Individuals working in SDCs are not considered as programme beneficiaries. ‘Personal Grievances [e.g. those related to conflict, instability or irregular migration] regarding income / livelihoods refer to complaints/criticisms/objections or a strong feeling from an individual programme beneficiary, that he/she has received an unfair (lack of) quantity or quality of income / livelihoods / economic perspective. How many individual programme beneficiaries sense that his/her grievances of having received (in the past) an unfair (lack of) quantity or quality of income / livelihoods have recently diminished, as a consequence (long term outcome) of having participated in income generating and livelihoods opportunities directed at the prevention of the (re)occurrence of conflict, instability and/or irregular migration.

title.narrative: Communities, men and women increasingly benefit from self-employment activities MSMEs increase their financial viability, productivity and job creation
Number and % of programme beneficiaries who indicate that their business / self-employment activities (which existed already before the grantees' interventions) have grown over the last 6 months

description.narrative: ‘Grown over the last six months’ is understood as having continued and improved the economic benefits of their business / self-employment activities (e.g. they have earned more money or better secured their livelihoods) or hired more staff.

title.narrative: Communities, men and women increasingly benefit from employment. Vulnerable individuals increase their participation to the private sector job market.
Number and % of trained/supported programme beneficiaries who have become employed.

description.narrative: ‘Trained/supported programme beneficiaries’ refers in this case to people to whom the intervention is directed, who have – at a moment when they were unemployed - either participated in skills development activities, or have received other support, in order to improve their employability. ‘Employed’: having a paid job, working the equivalent of at least 5 days per week (or 240 days/year), with or without a contract, paid roughly at the market wage rate (source: http://www.enterprise-development.org). Excludes self-employment, which is measured through a separate indicator. See guidance to understand how to calculate part-time jobs.
